name: Coherent Breathing
summary: A paced breathing practice that regulates the autonomic nervous system by aligning inhalations and exhalations to approximately 5–6 breaths per minute.
description: Coherent breathing is a therapeutic breathing technique that emphasizes slow, rhythmic breathing at a rate of around 5 to 6 breaths per minute, often synchronized with gentle counting or external cues. The practice promotes balance between the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, enhances heart rate variability (HRV), and supports physical and emotional regulation. It is commonly used for stress reduction, anxiety management, and overall well-being, and can be practiced independently or integrated into therapy and meditation programs.

practice_styles: Use of apps or biofeedback devices
delivery_methods: Mobile apps or wearables with breath pacing
metadata.training_required: No formal training required; often taught by therapists, yoga instructors, or via digital guides.
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated; available as self-help and wellness practice.

contraindications: Relative: Severe respiratory illness (e.g., advanced COPD) without medical supervision
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe for most people. Some may experience lightheadedness or discomfort if breathing is forced rather than relaxed.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate. Supported by research on HRV biofeedback and paced breathing interventions.

sections.text: Coherent breathing works by slowing respiration to around 5–6 breaths per minute, which promotes synchronization between breathing rhythms, heart rate, and blood pressure oscillations. This enhances vagal tone, increases heart rate variability (HRV), and shifts autonomic balance toward parasympathetic dominance, supporting relaxation and resilience to stress.

sections.preparation: Find a quiet, comfortable space. Sit or lie in a relaxed position.
procedure: Inhale gently through the nose for ~5–6 seconds.
Exhale gently through the nose for ~5–6 seconds.
Continue breathing at this pace for 10–20 minutes.
Optionally use a timer, app, or music with a slow rhythm to guide pacing.
sections.frequency: Daily practice recommended, at least once per day.

items: 5 breaths per minute for HRV optimization

relative: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) without supervision
special_considerations: Should be practiced gently; avoid forcing long inhales/exhales.

ideal_candidates: Patients looking to improve sleep and relaxation
screening_required: Respiratory health history if chronic illness present

lifestyle_recommendations: Practice before sleep for improved rest

sections.typical_session_cost: Generally free when self-practiced; guided sessions or apps may cost $10–$50/month
sections.insurance_coverage: Not typically covered; considered wellness practice

items: Strong overlap with HRV biofeedback research.
Most benefits require regular daily practice.
Simple, accessible technique with minimal risks.
